title: How to Qualify a General Contractor for Fix-and-Flip Projects
excerpt: Choosing the right general contractor can make or break your fix-and-flip investment. Use this targeted checklist to ensure your GC is licensed, insured, experienced, and ready to deliver profitable results on time and on budget.

content.text: Why Vetting Your GC Matters in Fix-and-Flip

In the fix-and-flip business, time is money. An unqualified general contractor can cause costly delays, budget overruns, and compliance headaches. Properly qualifying your GC helps you avoid these pitfalls, protects your investment, and keeps your project moving toward a profitable sale.
Key Checklist for Qualifying a General Contractor

items: Licensing: Confirm your GC has a valid state contractor’s license and no violations. In California, check the CSLB portal.
Insurance: Require proof of liability and workers’ comp insurance. Verify policies are active with the provider.
Experience: Look for at least five years in your market and a track record with similar rehab or flip projects. Review online ratings and check for unresolved complaints.
Crew Oversight: Ask if work is done by in-house staff or subcontractors and ensure all are covered by workers’ comp. Confirm who will supervise the project day-to-day.
Permits & Approvals: Ensure the GC will handle all city permits, code compliance, and secure the Certificate of Occupancy (CoFO). Expect regular progress updates.
Payment Schedule: Never pay in full upfront. Use milestone-based payments and withhold final payment until the project is complete and passes inspection.

Contract Terms: Insist on a detailed, signed contract covering itemized costs, timelines, payment milestones, insurance, permits, change orders, and warranties. Make sure the contract is clear and legally compliant.
Lack of experience with investment rehabs or flips

content.text: Your GC is a key partner in your fix-and-flip success. Take the time to vet them thoroughly, demand transparency, and don’t hesitate to walk away if you see warning signs. If you’re new to flipping or want to leverage top-tier GC relationships, consider partnering with experienced local investors or firms with a proven contractor network.
